summary:
=== Purchase Information === Review Date: 2019/03/07 Average Rating: 3.4 Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]', 'English Dialogue Boost: High', 'English Dialogue Boost: Medium'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Alex Gabassi'], 'Producers': ['Mammoth Screen LTD', 'Agatha Christie Productions LTD', 'Farah Abushwesha'], 'Starring': ['John Malkovich', 'Rupert Grint', 'Andrew Buchan']} Review Text: Utter garbage. They tried to make "art"please just give us entertainment.
If I could give it less stars I would. Malkovich is slipping in and out of Poirot's accent. So annoying.
If you want to make something gritty and modern and different ,maybe you should write something gritty and modern and different, not grab someone else's work. It's the built in audience you are after. I am glad Agatha Christie fans are not taking this laying down.
This show is a prime example why remakes are a cheap grab for views. Take something that is out there and you know was successful, repackage it , slap your stamp on it, slide it out and rake it in. You are not Agatha Christie. Please don't try to tell us this is Agatha Christie. This is a vanity project where someone was either too cheap, or not talented enough to write their own plot.
This is happening with Lost in Space and more recently STD (Star TrekDiscovery)is completely disrespecting fans of well established and well loved shows and trying to force us into a direction we never asked to go. Review Title: Utter trash Rating: 1.0 -------------------------------------------------- === Purchase Information === Review Date: 2019/03/07 Average Rating: 4.6 Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Olatunde Osunsanmi', 'Jonathan Frakes', 'Douglas Aarniokoski', 'Lee Rose', 'Christopher J. Byrne', 'Hanelle M. Culpepper', 'Jen McGowan', 'David Barrett', 'Akiva Goldsman', 'T.J. Scott'], 'Studio': ['CBS']} Review Text: My husband likes it. I am disappointed Review Title: Meh Rating: 1.0 -------------------------------------------------- === Purchase Information === Product Title: Doctor Thorne: Season 1 Review Date: 2020/06/12 Store: Alison Brie (Actor), Harry Richardson (Actor), Niall MacCormick (Director) & 0 more Rated: NR Format: DVD Categories: Movies & TV, Genre for Featured Categories, Drama Product Description: ["1855. When Doctor Thorne's penniless niece, Mary, is excluded from the wedding preparations of her childhood playmate, she probes her uncle for the truth of her birth. She is devastated to learn that she is the illegitimate child of his late brother. It seems she has neither breeding nor fortune. This is a problem, as Mary and the heir to the Greshamsbury Estate, Frank, have fallen in love. Frank is under strict instructions from his over-bearing mother, Lady Arabella, to save his family from financial ruin by marrying money. Frank's mother schemes to separate the two lovebirds, encouraging her son to woo the wealthy American heiress, Miss Dunstable. Meanwhile, Doctor Thorne acts as both physician and business advisor to railway millionaire, Sir Roger Scatcherd, in whose hands the fate of Greshamsbury lies and who is rapidly drinking himself into an early grave. Frank finally plucks up the courage to propose to Mary and Doctor Thorne gives him his blessing, but not before he has filled him in on the scandalous truth surrounding her birth. Lady Arabella continues her persecution of Mary, and is furious when Frank tells her he is set on marrying Doctor Thorne's penniless niece."] Average Rating: 4.7 Product Details: {'Genre': 'TV', 'Format': 'NTSC, Widescreen', 'Contributor': 'Rebecca Front, Niall MacCormick, Stefani Martini, Tom Hollander, Richard McCabe, Harry Richardson, Alison Brie, Ian McShaneRebecca Front, Niall MacCormick, Stefani Martini, Tom Hollander, Richard McCabe, Harry Richardson, Alison Brie, Ian McShane See more', 'Language': 'English', 'Number Of Discs': '1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'NR (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.72 Ounces', 'Item model number': '43212352', 'Director': 'Niall MacCormick', 'Media Format': 'NTSC, Widescreen', 'Run time': '2 hours and 59 minutes', 'Release date': 'October 18, 2016', 'Actors': 'Alison Brie, Harry Richardson, Ian McShane, Rebecca Front, Richard McCabe', 'Subtitles': 'Spanish', 'Studio': 'Lionsgate Home Entertainment', 'Number of discs': '1'} Review Text: The book is amazing. The movie is quite nice, but the rambling at the beginning and end of each episode is obnoxious. Review Title: The monologue is obnoxious Rating: 2.0 -------------------------------------------------- === Purchase Information === Review Date: 2020/06/12 Average Rating: 4.4 Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'sexual content'], 'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Niall MacCormick'], 'Producers': ['Helen Gregory']} Review Text: The ramblings of Mr. Fellow's at the beginning and end of each episode are, to say the least, obnoxious.
The book was SO much better.
Just a shame what they did to it. Review Title: Mr. Fellow's ramblings are obnoxious. Rating: 1.0 --------------------------------------------------

raw_response:
SUMMARY:  
The individual's purchase history reveals a strong preference for high-quality adaptations of classic literature, yet a notable dissatisfaction with recent interpretations and remakes. They consistently rate products with critical sentiments, reflecting a desire for authentic storytelling over modern reboots, and express disappointment when such adaptations fail to capture the original's essence. A recurring theme is their appreciation for character-driven narratives, particularly those set in historical contexts, with an inclination towards drama.

Quality preferences lean towards well-crafted productions, as evidenced by higher ratings for meticulously executed works, while they show sensitivity to perceived poor execution, such as excessive or irritating dialogue. The critic's engagement suggests they value innovative storytelling, but are highly critical of mediocrity, especially in adaptations of beloved works. Their purchasing behavior indicates selective choices, favoring critically acclaimed genres yet expressing strong disapproval when expectations are unmet.

In summary, this individual demonstrates a complex relationship with film and television, balancing high expectations for fidelity to source material with a disdain for derivative content, while favoring well-produced, character-centric drama.

target_interaction.title: Don't bother.
target_interaction.text:
Nothing even remotely Bronte about this movie.
I love Nordic noir. This movie tried too hard to come close. Endless landscapes and dark colours do not make noise. Nor do they make a good story. Actually.... there was no story. I watched half the movie and half of that on fast forward because it was so insipid. And I still was able to follow the shallow plot.
The acting was aweful. Two sisters with two different accents. The Irish one sounded scrottish half the time and hysterical the rest.
The French man lost his accent completely for a while.
It was all so disjointed.
I thought oh maybe someone's idea of an art film? But nope just someone trying too hard to be just like..... trying too hard to make it into a league they just aren't in.
Who directed this waste of celluloid?
I loved the landscape shots, but it seemed they were randomly thrown in every tine the director didn't know where to go next.
What a waste.
